metadata.case_name: Civil Appeal No. 438 of 1960 (Appellant v. State of Punjab & Ors.)

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court challenging appointments of five persons (respondents 2 to 6) as District Judges by State Government (respondent 1), claiming they were not qualified under Art. 233.
Punjab High Court summarily dismissed the writ petition on September 21, 1959.
Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court on August 19, 1960.

Respondents 2-6: Shamsher Bahadur appointed District Judge on March 20, 1950; now Additional Judge Punjab High Court. Called to Bar England Jan 26, 1933; enrolled Lahore High Court May 15, 1933; practiced till appointment.

Respondent 3 Harbans Singh: Enrolled Lahore High Court March 5, 1937; Additional DJ Ferozepore July 2, 1947 to Feb 22, 1948; Deputy Custodian till Apr 17, 1950; appointed DJ Apr 18, 1950; Additional Judge High Court Aug 11, 1958.
Respondent 4 Gurdev Singh: Pleader Lahore HC Oct 25, 1934; Advocate Dec 20, 1938; Federal Court May 29, 1948; practiced continuously; appointed DJ Feb 2, 1952; officiating Judge HC July 11, 1960.
Respondent 5 Hans Raj Khanna: Pleader Lahore HC July 17, 1934; Advocate Dec 20, 1940; practiced Amritsar; on roll East Punjab HC; appointed DJ Feb 1, 1952.

Respondent 6 P.R. Sawhney: Called to Bar Nov 17, 1930; enrolled Lahore HC Mar 10, 1931; post-partition various govt roles; license suspended May 6, 1949; enrolled Oct 20, 1959; appointed DJ Apr 6, 1957.
Three respondents (2,4,5) had names on roll of Advocates of Punjab HC before appointment as DJ; two (3,6) did not at time of appointment.
Appellant initially challenged HC appointments but gave up; Union of India struck off as respondent Mar 18, 1960; later intervened.
Interveners Om Dutt Sharma and B.D. Pathak challenged Sawhney's appointments due to acquittals in their cases.
Preliminary objection by some respondents: no longer DJs, quo warranto not maintainable; overruled by SC.
High Courts (Punjab) Order, 1947 cl.6: Recognized Lahore HC advocates in East Punjab HC; seniority preserved.
Bar Councils Act 1926 ss.3-16 into force East Punjab HC Sep 28, 1948; s.8 required roll preparation including prior advocates.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondents 2-6 fulfilled requirements of Art. 233(2): persons not already in service eligible only if been for not less than seven years an advocate or pleader and recommended by High Court.
Whether period of practice in Lahore High Court (pre-partition) counts towards seven years under Art. 233(2).
Meaning of 'advocate or pleader' and tense 'has been' in Art. 233(2); must be advocate at time of appointment and only in Indian courts post-1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Advocate or pleader means entitled to practise in Court in India; excludes foreign/former Lahore HC post-partition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Legal Practitioners Act 1879; CPC 1908; Bar Councils Act 1926

petitioner_arguments.text: Present perfect 'has been' requires must be advocate at time of appointment.
Seven years standing only in courts in territory of India post-1947.
Appointments violated statutory service rules reserving 1/3 posts for subordinate judicial service.

respondent_arguments.text: Lahore HC advocates recognized in East Punjab HC under cl.6 High Courts (Punjab) Order 1947; seniority preserved; automatically on roll under s.8(2)(a) Bar Councils Act 1926.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: High Courts (Punjab) Order 1947 cl.6; Bar Councils Act 1926 s.8

respondent_arguments.text: Harbans Singh in State service, Art.233(2) not applicable.
Alternative: Entitled to practise subordinate courts under s.4 Legal Practitioners Act 1879.

court_reasoning.text: Overruled preliminary objection; issue live as some may revert to DJ posts; State wants decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question of validity of initial appointments remains relevant.

court_reasoning.text: Post-partition: High Courts (Punjab) Order 1947 cl.6 recognized Lahore advocates in East Punjab HC with preserved seniority; Bar Councils Act s.8(2)(a) required their entry on roll.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Practice in Lahore HC counts towards standing; no loss of status.

court_reasoning.text: Three respondents on roll at appointment, practiced >7 years including Lahore period; eligible under Art.233(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even assuming petitioner's first two submissions, no objection.

court_reasoning.text: Harbans Singh and Sawhney: Recognized post-1947; automatically on roll post-1948; fee payment minor; continued as advocates.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Did not cease to be advocates; had >7 years standing.

court_reasoning.text: No statutory rule breach proven in service reservations.

holdings.text: Respondents 2-6 eligible under Art.233(2); appointments valid.
Lahore HC practice counts for 7 years standing via Order 1947 and Bar Councils Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mubarak Mazdoor v. K. K. Banerji
precedents_cited.relevance: Different meaning to similar expression in Representation of the People Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Eligibility for District Judges; interpretation of cl.2.

statutes_cited.name: Bar Councils Act, 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Roll of advocates; automatic entry for prior practitioners.

statutes_cited.name: High Courts (Punjab) Order, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Recognition of Lahore HC advocates in East Punjab HC; preserved seniority.

statutes_cited.name: Legal Practitioners Act, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Alternative right to practise subordinate courts (not relied upon).

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; appointments of respondents 2-6 as District Judges held valid under Art. 233; no breach of service rules proven.

key_quotes.text: "A person not already in the service of the Union or of the State shall only be eligible to be appointed a district judge if he has been for not less than seven years an advocate or, a pleader and is recommended by the High Court for appointment."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the seniority of advocates in the new High Court as to their right of audience was to be regulated by the principle in force in-the former High Court"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains preservation of Lahore HC standing.

key_quotes.text: "They did not cease to be advocates at any time or stage after August 15, 1947, and continued to be advocates of the Punjab High Court till they were appointed as District Judges."
key_quotes.speaker: court
